skills.name: Word problems involving dividing with or by unit fractions

explanations.A: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 3 not 1/2 x 3. Can the children get more than 1/2 a bar each?
explanations.B: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 3. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped the wrong fraction - can the children get more than 1/2 a bar each?
explanations.C: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 3. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped both fractions instead of just the second - can the children get more than 1/2 a bar each?
explanations.D: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 3. 1/2 ÷ 3/1 = 1/2 x 1/3 = 1/6.

explanations.A: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 2. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped the wrong fraction - can the children get more than 1/2 a bar each?
explanations.B: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 2 not 1/2 x 2. Can the children get more than 1/2 a bar each?
explanations.C: 1/2 a bar is being shared, so we want to do 1/2 ÷ 2. 1/2 ÷ 2/1 = 1/2 x 1/2 = 1/4.
explanations.D: We need to share the 1/2 a bar between 2 children so you are doing the calculation 1/2 ÷ 2 to find out how much each child gets...

explanations.A: 1/4 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/4 ÷ 12. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped both fractions instead of just the second - can each glass get more than 1/4 of a jug of water?
explanations.B: 1/4 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/4 ÷ 12 not 1/4 x 12 - can each glass get more than 1/4 of a jug of water?
explanations.C: 1/4 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/4 ÷ 12. 1/4 ÷ 12/1 = 1/4 x 1/12 = 1/48.
explanations.D: 1/4 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/4 ÷ 12. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped the first fraction instead of the second - can each glass get more than 1/4 of a jug of water?

explanations.A: 1/6 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/6 ÷ 10. 1/6 ÷ 10/1 = 1/6 x 1/10 = 1/60.
explanations.B: 1/6 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/6 ÷ 10. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped the first fraction instead of the second...
explanations.C: 1/6 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/6 ÷ 10. I think you might have used "Keep Flip Change" but flipped both fractions instead of just the second...
explanations.D: 1/6 of a jug is being shared out so we want to do 1/6 ÷ 10 not 1/6 x 10 - can each glass get more than 1/6 of a jug of water?

explanations.A: We want to know how many 1/2 tins are in 10 tins, so we do 10 ÷ 1/2 = 10 x 2 = 20. Or we can think each tin is used up in 2 days, so 10 tins are used up in 20 days.
explanations.B: Not quite - how many days would it take to use up 1 tin? So many days would it take to use up 10 tins?
explanations.C: Not quite - I think you may have done 10 ÷ 2 but we want 10 ÷ 1/2 to find out how many 1/2 tins are in 10 tins.
explanations.D: That's how many days it would take to use 1 tin, how many would it take to use 10 tins?

explanations.A: Not quite - how many days would it take to use up 1 tin? So many days would it take to use up 12 tins?
explanations.B: Not quite - I think you may have done 12 ÷ 4 but we want 12 ÷ 1/4 to find out how many 1/4 tins are in 12 tins.
explanations.C: We want to know how many 1/4 tins are in 12 tins, so we do 12 ÷ 1/4 = 12 x 4 = 48. Or we can think each tin is used up in 4 days, so 12 tins are used up in 48 days.
explanations.D: That's how many days it would take to use 1 tin, how many would it take to use 12 tins?

explanations.A: We are sharing 6 pizzas into thirds, so we want to do 6 ÷ 1/3 not 6 x 1/3. Would two people getting 1/3 of a pizza each make 6 pizzas in total?
explanations.B: 3 people getting 1/3 each would eat 1 pizza in total, so how many people would eat 6 pizzas in total?
explanations.C: We are sharing 6 pizzas into thirds, so we do 6 ÷ 1/3 = 6 x 3 = 18. Or you can think that one pizza would be shared by 3 people getting 1/3 each, so 6 pizzas would be shared by 6 x 3 = 18 people.
explanations.D: Not quite - if each person gets 1/3 of a pizza, how many people would share 1 pizza? So how many people would share 6 pizzas?

explanations.A: Not quite - if each person gets 1/3 of a pizza, how many people would share 1 pizza? So how many people would share 10 pizzas?
explanations.B: We are sharing 10 pizzas into thirds, so we do 10 ÷ 1/3 = 10 x 3 = 30. Or you can think that one pizza would be shared by 3 people getting 1/3 each, so 10 pizzas would be shared by 10 x 3 = 30 people.
explanations.C: 3 people getting 1/3 each would eat 1 pizza in total, so how many people would eat 10 pizzas in total?
explanations.D: We are sharing 10 pizzas into thirds, so we want to do 10 ÷ 1/3 not 10 x 1/3...

explanations.A: We want to know how many lots of 1/8 it takes to make 5, so we do 5 ÷ 1/8 = 5 x 8 = 40. Or you can think that it takes 8 laps to run 1 mile, so 5 x 8 = 40 laps to run 5 miles.
explanations.B: Not quite - if each lap is 1/8 of a mile how many laps will it take to run one mile? So how many laps to run 5 miles?
explanations.C: That would be the number of laps if each lap was one mile - if each lap is 1/8 of a mile how many laps will it take to run one mile? So how many laps to run 5 miles?
explanations.D: That's how many laps it would take to run 1 mile, so how many laps would it take to run 5 miles?

explanations.A: Not quite - if each lap is 1/9 of a mile how many laps will it take to run one mile? So how many laps to run 6 miles?
explanations.B: We want to know how many lots of 1/9 it takes to make 6, so we do 6 ÷ 1/9 = 6 x 9 = 54. Or you can think that it takes 9 laps to run 1 mile, so 6 x 9 = 54 laps to run 6 miles.
explanations.C: That's how many laps it would take to run 1 mile, so how many laps would it take to run 6 miles?
explanations.D: That would be the number of laps if each lap was one mile - if each lap is 1/9 of a mile how many laps will it take to run one mile? So how many laps to run 6 miles?
